trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised phase III trial of exemestane versus anastrozole in postmenopausal women with receptor positive primary breast cancer

interventions.interventions:
IBCSG 30-04 / NCIC CTG MA.27 is co-ordinated by the National Cancer Institute of Canada, Clinical Trials Group (NCIC CTG). The International Breast Cancer Study Group (IBCSG) is participating in the NCIC CTG MA.27 trial, and the ANZ Breast Cancer Trials Group (ANZ BCTG) contribution is part of the IBCSG collaboration. The trial is conducted in Australia and New Zealand by the ANZ Breast Cancer Trials Group.
This study will investigate which of two drugs (exemestane and anastrozole), if either, is better at preventing a recurrence of breast cancer in postmenopausal women with receptor positive, adequately excised, primary breast cancer.
IBCSG 30-04 / NCIC CTG MA.27 is an international, multicentre, randomised phase III clinical trial of 5800 postmenopausal women who have had histologically or cytologically confirmed, receptor-positive primary breast cancer.
Women will be randomised in a 2-arm design to receive one of the following:
a. Exemestane 25mg b. Anastrozole 1mg
All treatment will be on a daily basis for 5 years until recurrence or second malignancy is documented.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To compare event free survival between women treated with exemestane or anastrozole as adjuvant therapy. The total duration of the study will be about 5 years.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: It will be measured when 847 events have been observed. It is estmated that 3.2 years of accrual and another 2 years of follow up will be required.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To compare overall survival and time to distant recurrence of women treated with exemestane with that of those receiving anastrozole as adjuvant therapy.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Two interim analyses are planned for this study when 282 and 564 events are observed. It is projected that the analyses would be performed 2.7 and 3.9 years after the first patient is entered. Assuming a hazard ratio of 0.80 between exemestane and anastrozole is being detected, with a two-sided 5% level and 90% power, a total of 5800 patients accrued over 3.2 years will be needed and another 2 years of follow-up before 847 events are observed at the final analysis. The total duration of the study would be about 5 years.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To compare incidence of new primary contralateral breast cancer in the different treatment groups.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Two interim analyses are planned for this study when 282 and 564 events are observed. It is projected that the analyses would be performed 2.7 and 3.9 years after the first patient is entered. Assuming a hazard ratio of 0.80 between exemestane and anastrozole is being detected, with a two-sided 5% level and 90% power, a total of 5800 patients accrued over 3.2 years will be needed and another 2 years of follow-up before 847 events are observed at the final analysis. The total duration of the study would be about 5 years.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To compare incidence of all clinical fractures and specifically hip and vertebral fractures in the different treatment groups.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Two interim analyses are planned for this study when 282 and 564 events are observed. It is projected that the analyses would be performed 2.7 and 3.9 years after the first patient is entered. Assuming a hazard ratio of 0.80 between exemestane and anastrozole is being detected, with a two-sided 5% level and 90% power, a total of 5800 patients accrued over 3.2 years will be needed and another 2 years of follow-up before 847 events are observed at the final analysis. The total duration of the study would be about 5 years.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To compare cardiovascular morbidity and mortality between exemestane and anastrozole.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Two interim analyses are planned for this study when 282 and 564 events are observed. It is projected that the analyses would be performed 2.7 and 3.9 years after the first patient is entered. Assuming a hazard ratio of 0.80 between exemestane and anastrozole is being detected, with a two-sided 5% level and 90% power, a total of 5800 patients accrued over 3.2 years will be needed and another 2 years of follow-up before 847 events are observed at the final analysis. The total duration of the study would be about 5 years.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To examine whether breast density changes with aromatase inhibitor therapy and also whether these therapy-induced changes are associated with plasma hormones and growth factors.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Two interim analyses are planned for this study when 282 and 564 events are observed. It is projected that the analyses would be performed 2.7 and 3.9 years after the first patient is entered. Assuming a hazard ratio of 0.80 between exemestane and anastrozole is being detected, with a two-sided 5% level and 90% power, a total of 5800 patients accrued over 3.2 years will be needed and another 2 years of follow-up before 847 events are observed at the final analysis. The total duration of the study would be about 5 years.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Drug levels of exemestane or anastrozole, genetic variation and breast cancer recurrence or contralateral events.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Two interim analyses are planned for this study when 282 and 564 events are observed. It is projected that the analyses would be performed 2.7 and 3.9 years after the first patient is entered. Assuming a hazard ratio of 0.80 between exemestane and anastrozole is being detected, with a two-sided 5% level and 90% power, a total of 5800 patients accrued over 3.2 years will be needed and another 2 years of follow-up before 847 events are observed at the final analysis. The total duration of the study would be about 5 years.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To compare toxicities in the two different treatment groups.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Two interim analyses are planned for this study when 282 and 564 events are observed. It is projected that the analyses would be performed 2.7 and 3.9 years after the first patient is entered. Assuming a hazard ratio of 0.80 between exemestane and anastrozole is being detected, with a two-sided 5% level and 90% power, a total of 5800 patients accrued over 3.2 years will be needed and another 2 years of follow-up before 847 events are observed at the final analysis. The total duration of the study would be about 5 years.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Postmenopausal women with completely resected, histologically proven, hormone receptor-positive primary breast cancer who have a minimum life expectancy of 5 years and are accessible for follow up.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Premenopausal women; patients with only receptor negative primary tumours; patients with locally recurrent or metastatic breast cancer; patients with history of other (non-breast) malignancies; patients receiving concurrent hormonal therapy with estrogens, progesterones, androgens, or SERMs; patients having received prior treatment with a recognised aromatase inhibitor; any prior treatment with tamoxifen or SERMS other than raloxifene; any prior treatment with hormones or steroids if not discontinued at least 3 weeks prior to randomization; patients with a prior diagnosis of an in-situ carcinoma in the contralateral breast treated with partial mastectomy and/or hormonal therapy.

trial_design.concealment: The ANZ BCTG Statistical Centre at the NHMRC Clinical Trials Centre, University of Sydney will provide a central randomisation service by fax for all Australian and New Zealand institutions. At the time of study entry all participants will be allocated a treatment code via a web-based randomization system and study drug will be supplied in accordance with the treatment code.
trial_design.sequence: Randomisation will be performed via a web-based computerised system, stratification by lymph node status and prior adjuvant chemotherapy (yes/no).

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Australia and New Zealand Breast Cancer Trials Group Ltd

ethicsAndSummary.summary: For further information, please see www.clinicaltrials.gov NCT00066573
